Question: Can tuition and other school fees be paid in full at the time of enrollment?
Answer: Yes, tuition and other school fees may be paid in full at the time of enrollment or by installment (amount set by the Office of Finance).

Question: Where can students pay their fees?
Answer: Students can pay their fees at the cashier which is located at the ground floor of Bunzel building, or through online means.

Question: Are there discounts available for students who pay their fees in full?
Answer: Yes, discounts are granted on full payment of school fees within the specified period set by the Office of Finance.

Question: How do students avail of the discount?
Answer: Students who wish to avail of the discount are advised to apply at the Accounting Office within a specified time during the enrollment period; otherwise, the privilege will be forfeited.

Question: Can students pay their fees on an installment basis?
Answer: Yes, students who cannot pay their tuition and other fees in full during enrollment may settle their account on an installment basis, provided that the downpayment is made at enrollment according to the amount fixed by the University, and the balance must be paid monthly or on scheduled examination dates.

Question: How can teachers view the payment status of students?
Answer: The payment status of students can be viewed by teachers on the class lists in ISMIS.

Question: What is the penalty for a student who withdraws their enrollment within the enrollment period during the regular semester or summer term?
Answer: A student who withdraws his or her enrollment within the enrollment period during the regular semester of summer term shall be charged P500.00 non-refundable.

Question: What is the penalty for a student who withdraws their enrollment within the first week of classes during a regular semester or within the first to third day of classes during a summer term?
Answer: A student who withdraws his or her enrollment within the first week of classes during a regular semester or within the first to third day of classes during a summer term shall be charged matriculation fee plus 10% of the remaining total school fees.

Question: What is the penalty for a student who withdraws their enrollment within the second week of classes during a regular semester or within the fourth to sixth day of classes during a summer term?
Answer: A student who withdraws his or her enrollment within the second week of classes during a regular semester or within the fourth to sixth day of classes during a summer term shall be charged matriculation fee plus 20% of the remaining total school fees.

Question: What is the penalty for a student who withdraws their enrollment after the second week of classes during a regular semester or from the seventh day of classes onwards during a summer term?
Answer: A student who withdraws his or her enrollment after the second week of classes during a regular semester or from the seventh day of classes onwards during a summer term shall be charged 100% of the total school fees.

Question: Is a refund possible if a student withdraws during the enrollment period?
Answer: Yes, a refund of the amount paid (less processing charges and less non-refundable matriculation fees) shall be made if the student withdraws during the enrollment period, but prior to the opening of classes.

Question: Are there discounts available for members of the same family enrolled in the University?
Answer: Yes, members of the same family, that is, brothers and sisters, enrolled during the regular academic year/semester in any of the basic education departments and/or undergraduate colleges of the University (except Montessori, Law, and Graduate programs) are granted a five (5%) percent discount each on tuition fees only or as prescribed by the Office of Finance.

Question: Is there a limit to the number of students who can avail of the family discount?
Answer: Yes, this shall be limited to just four (4) students.

Question: Where can application forms for fee adjustment for children of University employees and members of the same family be obtained?
Answer: Application forms for fee adjustment for children of University employees and members of the same family are available at the Office of the Vice President for Finance.

Question: What determines the curricular year of a student?
Answer: The number of units earned in the curriculum of his/her program.

Question: What is the condition for a student to be considered full-time?
Answer: If he/she carries a regular load prescribed in his/her curriculum for a given time.

Question: Can a course be taken ahead of its prerequisite?
Answer: No, otherwise, it shall be nullified and taken again even if the student is graduating.

Question: What is the rule for laboratory courses?
Answer: They should be taken with the corresponding lecture courses in the same semester even though separate grades are earned.

Question: What happens if a student withdraws from a co-requisite course?
Answer: Both courses should be withdrawn together.

Question: Can a failed co-requisite course be re-enrolled without re-enrolling the other course the student has passed?
Answer: Yes.

Answer: No.

Question: What is the condition for a student to apply for an overload of not more than six (6) units?
Answer: The student is graduating at the end of the year; has not incurred more than five (5) failures (a grade of 5.0) in those terms that he/she was enrolled at the university; and has a grade point average (GPA) of at least 2.8.

Answer: Grades of 5.0 and NC are included.

Question: What is simultaneous enrollment?
Answer: A student may be allowed to enroll in the pre-requisite course and the advanced course simultaneously in order to graduate during his/her final term.

Question: What is the restriction for simultaneous enrollment?
Answer: It is restricted to only a particular two-subject load.

Question: What happens if a student fails in the prerequisite(s) in simultaneous enrollment?
Answer: He/she would have to retake all the advanced courses affected and the enrollment for the advanced courses automatically becomes null and void.

Answer: Starting on the third year of a four-year program and on the fourth year of a five-year program.

Question: What is a petitioned/tutorial course?
Answer: A course that may be requested for opening as a petitioned or tutorial class subject to certain conditions.

Question: What are the conditions for a petitioned/tutorial course?
Answer: It is an off-semester course; it is a prerequisite course for the next semester offering; it is the only course left for the students to graduate at the end of the term; there should be at least six (6) students for the petitioned course and five (5) students or less for the tutorial course; and a laboratory course can only be requested as a petitioned course.

Question: What is an override course?
Answer: The override rule due to an INC grade of a prerequisite course in favor of an advanced course.

Question: When can an override course be allowed?
Answer: In the last academic year prior to graduation, and for a subsequent course that requires Internship/Practicum as a requisite in case the student is still completing the said Internship/Practicum.

Question: What is the basis for accreditation of courses?
Answer: Equivalence in course content and level of instruction.

Answer: A final grade of 2.5 (B- = 80%) or higher if taken from PAASCU-accredited degree programs and a final grade of 2.0 (B+ = 85%) or higher if taken from non-PAASCU accredited degree programs.

Question: What is the basis for validating examinations?
Answer: The Course Chair administers validating examinations to students who do not meet the required final grade.

Question: What is the condition for accrediting courses taken abroad?
Answer: A final grade of 2.0 (B = 85%) or higher.

Answer: The student is expected to complete the program within the period specified in the program.

Question: What is the Maximum Allowable Residency (MAR)?
Answer: Equal to the required number of years to complete the course multiplied by 1.5.

Question: What is the effect of not filing a leave of absence?
Answer: The period covered by the student’s absence shall continue to be counted towards his/her Maximum Allowable Residency (MAR).

Answer: The student shall be disqualified to graduate with honors since a continuous enrollment is a requirement.

Question: What is expected of students in their relationship with their teachers?

Question: What is a minor offense?
Answer: Minor violations do not involve serious injury or harm, lack evidence of malice or premeditation, behaviors can be attributed to development or circumstances, and have little or no serious negative implications for the University or its members.

Question: What is the process for handling a very serious offense?
Answer: Step 1: The Chair of the Student Discipline Board (SDB) receives the case documents from the SDMC. Step 2: The Chair of the SDB furnishes copies of the case documents within 5 working days upon receipt thereof to all members of the committee for them to review, assess and study. Step 3: The SDB Chair convenes the members not more than 5 working days after furnishing copies of the case documents to the members of the SDB. Step 4: The SDB evaluates, assesses and reviews the findings of the case. Step 5: The SDB makes the final decision/judgement of the case. Step 6: The decision of the SDB shall become final and executory after 5 working days after the SDB has been convened. Step 7: The Student Discipline Officer facilitates the enforcement of the final decision.

Question: What is a student organization?
Answer: A student organization is an organized group of students sharing common interests, objectives, philosophy, and operational activities not contrary to laws, morals and University rules and regulations.

Question: What is the significance of student organizations in the University?
Answer: The University regards the formation of student organizations as a healthy sign of growing social awareness and concern and as an exercise of students’ freedom of association.

Question: What are the responsibilities that come with the freedom of association?
Answer: The responsibility to respect the freedom of others and to uphold the dignity of the student body as a whole.

Question: What are the venues that student organizations provide for students?
Answer: The development of students’ talents, potentials and capabilities; students’ greater awareness of their rights, duties and responsibilities; wholesome social and recreational activities; and the realization of the university’s mission statement and academic aims.

Question: How are student organizations categorized?
Answer: Student organizations are broadly categorized into two, namely: Co-curricular and Extra-curricular.

Question: What are Co-curricular organizations?
Answer: Co-curricular organizations are school/department-based and whose membership is automatic upon enrollment in a particular course or college.

Question: What are Extra-curricular organizations?
Answer: Extra-curricular organizations are initiated and organized by students to accommodate specific interests, concerns or visions, e.g. socio-civic, cultural, religious, athletic, professional service clubs, etc. and whose membership is voluntary.

Question: Why are student organizations allowed to initiate and organize activities?
Answer: To complement and enhance the learning process.

Question: Who manages the activities of student organizations?
Answer: Schools, departments, and student organizations, in coordination with the Office of Student Formation and Activities (OSFA), manage these activities.

Question: When should student organization activities be held?
Answer: Activities must be held within the academic calendar, and should not be scheduled a week before and during major examinations and institutional celebrations unless the activities are intrinsically related therewith.

Question: Who has general supervision of all activities of registered student organizations?
Answer: The Student Activities Officer shall have general supervision of all activities of registered student organizations as well as the student body.

Question: When should student organizations register or renew their registration?
Answer: At the beginning of the school year.

Question: What are the requirements for student organization registration?
Answer: The Constitution and/or By-laws or its equivalent, Program of Activities Form, Officers’ and Faculty Adviser’s Data Sheet, list of members and endorsements of authorized university officers or mother clubs for affiliated organizations.

Question: What happens after complying with the registration requirements?
Answer: Student organizations shall then be entitled to official recognition by the University through OSFA.

Question: What should I do if many of the Officers in my organization are no longer returning?
Answer: Check your Constitution and By-Laws for the appointment or election procedures. If it is not feasible to follow through, the suggestion is to function with the human resources you have for as long as the goals of the organization can be met.

Question: What if the goals of the organization cannot be met?
Answer: The suggestion is to reduce the goals to only its most essential in carrying out the purpose of the organization.

Question: How can student organizations collect funds?
Answer: For Co-curricular Organizations, you may request for your fees to be included in the collection reflected on ISMIS through your Department. For Extracurricular Organizations, you may employ your preferred method of collection.
